Package io.atomix

Core Atomix APIs for creating and operating on distributed objects.

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    Atomix
    Base type for creating and managing distributed resources in a Atomix cluster.
    AtomixClient
    Provides an interface for creating and operating on Resources remotely.
    AtomixClient.Builder
    Builder for programmatically constructing an AtomixClient.
    AtomixReplica
    Provides an interface for creating and operating on Resources as a stateful node.
    AtomixReplica.Builder
    Builder for programmatically constructing an AtomixReplica.
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    AtomixReplica.Type
    Defines the behavior of a replica within the Atomix cluster.

Package io.atomix Description

Core Atomix APIs for creating and operating on distributed objects.

The Atomix cluster

This package provides the primary mechanisms for creating and managing Atomix clusters. An Atomix cluster consists of one or more replicas and any number of clients. To create a cluster, construct an AtomixReplica. 
   
   Address address = new Address("localhost", 5000);
   List<Address> members = Arrays.asList(
     new Address("localhost", 5000),
     new Address("localhost", 5001),
     new Address("localhost", 5002)
   );

   AtomixReplica replica = AtomixReplica.builder(address, members)
     .withTransport(new NettyTransport())
     .withStorage(new Storage("logs"))
     .withQuorumHint(3)
     .withBackupCount(1)
     .build();
   replica.open();
Atomix is built on the Raft consensus algorithm and so state changes in the Atomix cluster are quorum-based. This typically necessitates clusters of 3 or 5 nodes.

But Atomix is designed to be embedded and scale in clusters much larger than the typical 3 or 5 node consensus based cluster. To do so, Atomix assigns a portion of the cluster to participate in the Raft algorithm, and the remainder of the replicas participate in asynchronous replication or await failures as standby nodes. A typical Atomix cluster may consist of 3 active Raft-voting replicas, 2 backup replicas, and any number of reserve nodes. As replicas are added to or removed from the cluster, Atomix transparently balances the cluster to ensure it maintains the desired number of active and backup replicas.

Atomix clusters are configured by setting the desired number of Raft participating nodes - known as the quorum hint - and the desired number of backup replicas - the backup count. Given these two parameters, Atomix clusters balance themselves to ensure that at least the desired number of replicas are participants in the Raft consensus algorithm at any time.

The size of the quorum is relevant both to performance and fault-tolerance. When resources are created or deleted or resource state changes are submitted to the cluster, Atomix will synchronously replicate changes to a majority of the cluster before they can be committed and update state. For example, in a cluster where the quorumHint is 3, a DistributedMap.put(Object, Object) command must be sent to the leader and then synchronously replicated to one other replica before it can be committed and applied to the map state machine. This also means that a cluster with quorumHint equal to 3 can tolerate at most one failure.

Backup replicas receive state changes asynchronously after they're committed via the Raft participating replicas. Further replicating state changes to backup replicas allows active replicas to be easily replaced in the event of a failure. If an active member of the Raft cluster is partitioned or crashes, Atomix will attempt to replace it with a backup replica if possible. Because the backup is largely caught up to the partitioned replica, replacing the Raft replica is a quick and painless operation. This allows Atomix clusters to handle failures of a majority of the cluster so long as a majority of the Raft replicas do not fail simultaneously.

Resources

Atomix replicas manage and replicate state, and both replicas and clients provide the interface to operate on that state. The Atomix interface provides the methods necessary to manage creating and operating on Resources. A resource is a stateful, fault-tolerant, distributed object that's manged by a replicated state machine. To create a resource, simply call Atomix.getResource(java.lang.String, io.atomix.resource.ResourceType) or use one of the getResource methods like Atomix.getMap(java.lang.String). 
   
   DistributedGroup group = atomix.getGroup("group").get();
A resource is simply an interface to a replicated state machine. When a resource is created, a state machine is created on each server or replica in the cluster, and operations on the resource are submitted to the cluster where they're logged, replicated, and applied to the resource's specific ResourceStateMachine.

Clients vs Replicas

The sole difference between clients and replicas is the ability to store state and participate in replication. Clients operate on resource state purely remotely. When a resource created by an AtomixClient is modified, operations are submitted remotely to the cluster. The same is true of replicas; when operations are performed on a resource created via an AtomixReplica, state changes may be performed remotely, but the replica also participates in the replication and commitment of the state changes. This allows servers to be effectively be embedded in code that operates on resource state.
Author:
Jordan Halterman
